thread.title: How many people watched the Buffalo Bills-Jacksonville Jaguars game on Yahoo?
thread.title_full: How many people watched the Buffalo Bills-Jacksonville Jaguars game on Yahoo?

author: Brent Axe | baxe@syracuse.com
title: How many people watched the Buffalo Bills-Jacksonville Jaguars game on Yahoo?
text:
Comments 
The numbers are in for the Buffalo Bills-Jacksonville Jaguars web stream via Yahoo Sports from London on Sunday and they are impressive. 
Yahoo announced Monday that more than 15.2 million unique viewers watched the game, with 33.6 million streams across all devices, streaming a total of 460 million minutes of game action. 
J acksonville beat Buffalo 34-31 at Wembley Stadium in London. 
According to Yahoo , about two-thirds of the streams were in the United States and about one-third were from other countries, which means the NFL got about 11.2 million streams from outside the U.S. Despite the immense size of the audience, Yahoo provided a great technical experience delivering the game. The stream reached HD levels, the average rebuffering ratio was nearly 1 percent and the game was broadcast at 60 frames per second. Average Internet video is usually distributed at 30 frames per second. 
Yahoo said that by comparison, 1.8 million unique users tuned into the WatchESPN app for the 2014 World Cup final between Germany and Brazil and that Sunday's audience was almost twice the size of the average audience (7.9 million) that TBS attracted for last week's NLCS between the Chicago Cubs and New York Mets. 
"It's been a great opportunity to partner with the NFL and deliver a truly exceptional global live streaming experience for our users," said Adam Cahan, Yahoo's SVP of Product and Engineering, in a statement. "We're seeing a dramatic shift in the industry as audiences' primary video watching moves away from TV. We were thrilled to join the NFL in setting a new standard for sports programming for our users and advertisers." Pro Football Talk notes that the NFL is expected to continue with the streamed games experiment. 
Sunday's Bills-Jaguars game was the first time that international viewers were able to access a NFL game without cable or satellite. 
The NFL's TV contracts with CBS for Sunday afternoon AFC games, FOX for Sunday afternoon NFC games, NBC for Sunday night games, ESPN for Monday night games and DirecTV for Sunday Ticket all run through 2022, but internet streaming is seen as a new source of distribution and revenue for the NFL in the future.
